progfund

Class CharList

  • java.lang.Object
    • progfund.CharList

  • public class CharList
extends java.lang.Object

    Overview

    This assignment will require you to write a class to represent a resizable array of characters. It should act much like a String. Unlike a String however, the characters can be changed or deleted directly.

    To make your life easier you will be provided with an API specification (just like the JavaDocs you use for your programming). Your job is to follow this API to fill out the method stubs with appropriate code. You should also ensure that this code is as uncrashable as possible. If your code detects faulty/incorrect input it should handle it as instructed in the API.

    Data Structure

    We will be storing chars into an array within the CharList class. Something to note is that arrays are immutable (They cannot be changed once they are created.) A large part of this assignment is to add methods to the CharList class to simulate an array that is mutable. These methods should facilitate adding and deleting chars from the array and changing the array's size. Your array must always be exactly the size necessary to fit all the characters. There must be no null chars on the end.

    Testing

    To ensure your code is uncrashable you will have to filter out incorrect input with if statements. A test driver has been provided to help you test your classes. However, you should write your own main method to test your classes as well. Test the expected input, test the boundary cases, test outside the boundary cases and test the ridiculous cases. Test early and test thoroughly.

    How To Do The Assignment

    We suggest you write your code in the order that the methods appear in. The most independent methods are listed first. More dependent methods are written last. You can call your earlier methods to complete the later methods. For example, deleteChar() might call charAt().

    You can write your own main method in this class to test only the methods which you have completed. You might consider printing out the contents of the array to make sure it contains the correct characters and length.

    Additional Requirements

    You must provide an academic integrity statement at the top of each class you write. This should include your name, id number, date and the statement, "This is my own work as defined by the SAIBT / EIBT Academic Misconduct policy." You will need to comment your code thoroughly while you are programming.

    In general, you may not use methods from other classes. The only exceptions are string.length() and string.charAt() may be used in your constructor and Character.toUpperCase(c) may be used in the toTitleCase() method. The use of other Java methods may result in a loss of marks.

        public char charAt(int index)
        Return the char at the argument index from the characters array.
        Parameters:
        index - the position of the char to return.
        Returns:
        The char at the given index or '\0' if no char is available.

      • toCharArray

        public char[] toCharArray()
        Return a deep copy of the characters array. Create a new array and loop through the characters array copying them to the new array.
        Returns:
        A char array deep copying the contents of the characters instance variable.

      • append

        public void append(CharList other)
        Add the argument charlist to the end of this charlist. The resulting array will be the length of both charlists added together.
        Parameters:
        other - The CharList to add.

      • prepend

        public void prepend(CharList other)
        Add the argument char list to the start of this charlist. The resulting array will be the length of both charlists added together.
        Parameters:
        other - The CharList to add.

      • insert

        public void insert(CharList other,
                   int index)
        Add the argument charlist at the specified index in the array. All characters at that index or beyond will be pushed to the end.
        Parameters:
        other - The CharList to insert.
        index - The position to insert at.

      • getRange

        public CharList getRange(int start,
                         int end)
        Return the substring in the range from start up to and excluding end.
        Parameters:
        start - Index of first character.
        end - Index of the character to stop before.
        Returns:
        A CharList representing the chars in this range. If start is less than zero, or end is greater than length or start and end are reversed, return null.

      • indexOf

        public int indexOf(CharList substring)
        Searches through the characters in this CharList for the sequence matching the argument CharList.
        Parameters:
        substring - Substring to find.
        Returns:
        The index of the first character of the substring or -1 if not in the CharList.

      • deleteChar

        public boolean deleteChar(int index)
        Deletes the char at the argument index. Characters will be shifted back to fill in the empty space. The char array will be resized to fit only the non null characters. Any blank space must be removed such that "racecar".deleteChar(3) results in the CharList "raccar".
        Parameters:
        index - position of char to delete.
        Returns:
        true if index is within the bounds of the array.

      • deleteRange

        public boolean deleteRange(int start,
                           int end)
        Deletes the substring from the arguments start (inclusive) to end (exclusive). Any blank space must be removed such that "abcdefg".deleteRange(1, 4) results in "aefg".
        Parameters:
        start - index of the char to start at.
        end - index of the char to stop before.
        Returns:
        true if the range was successfully deleted.

      • deleteSubstring

        public int deleteSubstring(CharList substring)
        Deletes the first instance of the argument substring if it is found in this CharList. Any blank space must be removed such that "racecar".deleteSubstring("cec") results in the CharList "raar".
        Parameters:
        substring - The string to find.
        Returns:
        the index of the first character in the substring that was deleted or -1 if the substring was not found.

      • toTitleCase

        public void toTitleCase()
        Capitalizes the first letter of each word in the CharList. You may use Character.toUpperCase(chr).

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(CharList other)
        Compares the chars of the argument CharList to the chars of the calling object. The Strings will be compared lexicographically such that Bed < Bread < Eggs < Milk < Mouse.
        Parameters:
        other - The CharList to compare
        Returns:
        1 if the calling object has a greater string than the argument. -1 if the calling object has a lesser string to the argument. 0 if the strings of the argument and calling objects are the same.
